title: Papers and patents are becoming less disruptive over time - Nature

last_post.content:
Has science become less 'disruptive'?
Nature news claimed so earlier this week: https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-022-04577-5
The claim is based on a bibliometric study that operationalizes disruptiveness in a particular way: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-05543-x

I wouldn't have noticed, but two journalists asked me about it. Some of my comments in a nutshell: 1/n

If you’re at the right place at the right time, with the right equipment, this is possible.

Last night, with guidance from https://transit-finder.com/, I positioned myself along the narrow line where the International #SpaceStation would pass between me and the nearly full moon.

I used a Fujifilm X-T4 shooting 4K video through a Celestron 8” SCT to capture the pass. Then, back at the computer this morning, put together these views with PIPP, Registax, and GIMP.

Quite pleased. My best yet.

Fascinating study: "The cognitive sciences have been dominated by English-speaking researchers studying other English speakers…However, English differs from other languages in ways that have consequences for the whole of the cognitive sciences…The particular characteristics of English and the linguistic habits of English speakers bias the field."
https://www.cell.com/trends/cognitive-sciences/fulltext/S1364-6613(22)00236-4

#MultilingualResearch, #Multilingualism, #CogSci

Excellent post-mortem of the Beaker Browser project: https://github.com/beakerbrowser/beaker/blob/master/archive-notice.md

I loved the Beaker vision when I first saw it, which I would describe as bringing some of the values of 2000s era FTP web development together with local-first, IPFS, and the modern web.

My takeaway here is that it's hard to combine "big vision + values for the future of computing" with "solve and immediate problem for people."

title: How Twitter misleads us about how many people have left — and what to do about it

last_post.content:
Who do so many people seem unaware of the mass exodus from Twitter?

Social media feeds are engines for distorting our social understanding. But we can push back against the algorithm, with a simple automated out-of-office message on Twitter (how-to included).

This post explains the science of social influence that allows Twitter to maintain an illusion of a full room, how to change that, & why we need industry-independent science for our digital environments.

https://natematias.medium.com/how-twitter-misleads-us-about-how-many-people-have-left-and-what-to-do-about-it-bba484b6fed6

Remember last week's research paper where a group of Chinese researchers clamed that they can break 2048-bit RSA with a quantum computer with only 372 qubits?

Turns out, the leading quantum computing expert in the world has something to say about it: it's bullshit.

"All told, this is one of the most actively misleading quantum computing papers I’ve seen in 25 years, and I’ve seen … many."

#cryptography

title: The turtle moms that ‘talk’ to their eggs before they hatch

last_post.content:
Ok, this is cool: a team of biologists worked out that turtles can talk. The hatchlings even talk to each other in the egg to coordinate their hatching. Turtle talk is at frequencies not very audible for humans and it can take hours for some species to reply to each other.

“Had we had a bit more expansive imaginations, we might have caught this earlier,” said Karen Bakker, a fellow at Harvard’s Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2023/01/06/turtles-eat-south-america/

title: Notifications: why less is more — how Facebook has been increasing both user satisfaction and app usage by sending only a few notifications

last_post.content:
Facebook discovers that if you bug people incessantly you increase short-term results by sacrificing in the long-term.

The opposite is also true. If you focus on communicating more selectively with value, you see worse results initially BUT end up in a stronger, more sustainable position.

Reminds you of choices we make in fundraising?

Loyalty wins.

(Also confirms my pet theory that for-profits are becoming more and more like nonprofits. :-)

#longterm #fundraising

title: Language models can only write poetry

last_post.content:
somehow missed this excellent essay by @aparrish on why language models can *only* write poetry

dovetails really well with my recent thinking about simulation (esp social sim) as a medium & why it feels to me less narrative than poetic somehow. the sim outputs we most value are the ones where the machine accidentally says more than it knows how to intend – where it's *trying* to enframe a story in terms it understands but something important *escapes* its understanding

title: This Is How They Wiped Themselves in Ancient Rome - JSTOR Daily

last_post.content:
I've been researching how ancient civilizations cleaned their butts after pooping (I'm writing a book!) and y'all, the Ancient Greeks were SUPER punk rock. They used bits of broken ceramic like a scoop (don't worry - the edges were smoothed out) and sometimes THE BITS OF POTTERY WERE INSCRIBED WITH THE NAMES OF THEIR ENEMIES.

They literally wiped their butts with their enemies' names. I am in awe.

title: Furby 1998 source code : David Hampton, Wayne Schulz : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive

last_post.content:
The Furby source code is public and heavily commented. For example, it turns the microphone off when the motors are running.

Furby was the 1998 version of ChatGPT and tons of people thought it actually slowly learned English words. The NSA was alarmed. However it turned out the "learning" process was just on a timer and the "microphone" only triggers on loud sounds.

In "ConvNeXt V2: Co-designing and Scaling ConvNets with Masked Autoencoders" researchers co-design the convolutional network architecture with masked autoencoding for self-supervised learning: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.00808

The Chronocyclegraph was developed by Frank Gilbreth and his wife, Lillian in the early 20th century. The couple employed small lamps on worker's hands and time-lapse photography to reduce a work cycle to the most efficient sequence. Gilbreth was the first to propose that a nurse could assist the surgeon, by handing them surgical instruments. He also devised the techniques used to teach how to rapidly disassemble and reassemble weapons.

https://we-make-money-not-art.com/the_chronocyclegraph/

title: GitHub - rougier/book-mode: A clean interface for org files (Emacs)

last_post.content: #emacs Book mode is an attempt at offering an interface for reading org-mode files with a clean layout. It is based on the use of large margins, headline and mode-line, with leading stars and bullets in the left margin using right alignment and different symbols. All decorations are part of the header-line (including upper left colored part and right upper glyph) and messages are displayed in the mode-line. Code at https://github.com/rougier/book-mode

The journal Meta-Psychology envisions a radically open way to publish.

It is free to publish in, open access, open peer review. Data and materials are required to be made publicly available. All statistical analyses are reproduced by their team to ensure reproducibility. They allow "evolving papers" where updates, replications, commentaries are added as links in the original paper webpage.

https://open.lnu.se/index.php/metapsychology/index
